Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2009 10:35PM bkc wrote: Everyminute, My left wrist started hurting about a week ago. Sometimes if I moved my wrist a certain way I would get a sharp pain and it hurt like heck. Couldn't do much of anything that required twisting or holding any thing that was the least bit heavy. Woke up this morning and it isn't hurting any more. Don't know what it was but what ever it is gone.
Posts.Title: new day new problem everyminute bkc

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 02:23PM bkc wrote: I have three more weeks of rad left and see the oncologist on a weekly basis. That is just the way my facility does it. I also see the  skin specialist once a week. Both Doctors are available if the techs see a problem but it is required that each patient see both Dr. at least once a week. Thank God my facility is only a fifteen minute trip away.I have been complaining about having my days interrupted and wanting this part of it to hurry up and be over. No more complaining for me!
Posts.Title: How important is your rad. oncologist? LisaF LisaF

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 05:30PM bkc wrote: Apple, That is to funny. My husband says we have a hamper for dirty clothes so why not a clean laundry basket for each child to put clean clothes in? And why should you rinse dishes before you put them in the dishwasher? I don't argue. He's making dinner tonight.
Posts.Title: How help my wife through chemo? Husband11 Ninja

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 10:38PM bkc wrote: My drs. are all very good about not keeping me waiting long but my girls Pedi. is absolutely ridiculous. They always take us in the back way so I am not exposed to sick kids but then we wait in a little 8x10 room for 2 or 3 hours. Imagine doing that with an active 4 and 5 year old. The pedi is never on time and can be 2 or 3 hours late at times. Last time this happened I finally got aggravated and told the nurse we would wait outside for the Dr. When she showed up my 4 year old said "Why you take sooooo long. You should get a clock." Wonder if I can bill her for my time?
Posts.Title: Why do doctors think our time is not valuable? LuAnnH bmdaley

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 11:56AM bkc wrote: Timothy you hang in there. My husband is also my greatest supporter. We have two young children 4 and 5 year old girls plus an 18 year old son and two older children. My husband and My 18 year old have been my rocks. I don't know what I would do without them. It was really hard for me to give up control of alot of the every day stuff but my husband and son managed beautifully. Even my babies were troopers and learned quickly how to pick up after themselves and give me hugs without hurting my booboos. My husband did the honors of shaving my head. My son and brother-in- law also shaved thier heads.(My husband doesn't have enough hair to shave) I never wore a wig didn't want to deal with that but everyone sent me great caps and hats and that was fine for me. I joined a bc support group and these ladies are now my dear friends. I have learned that this is not my fight alone and that my husband my kids and everyone around me are going through an emotional event. It is ok to cry,it is ok to scream at the top of your lungs and it is ok not to know what to say or do. But just a silent hug is wonderful for her and for you. I hope this helps.
Posts.Title: How help my wife through chemo? Husband11 Ninja

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 11:22AM bkc wrote: I to love the port.(If you can love anyting about this) Not thru treatment so its still there but Dr. said it was best because it could be used for chemo and all those blood samples thus preventing vein break down. Only a tiny scar that healed quickly and started chemo week after insertion. I had very little pain and almost forget it's there sometimes. And the best part they don't have to dig around looking for a vain. Doesn't hurt at all when they take blood or flush the port.
Posts.Title: How help my wife through chemo? Husband11 Ninja

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 11:59AM bkc wrote: KerryMac My girls are 5 and 4  but they were little troopers. Helped me out alot and were very gentle with mom and her big booboo. It was tuff but my 18 year old son was awesome and my husband took over alot of stuff. Going thru rads now so they are still helping a bunch. One thing the Onc. told me was to delay my kids shots because some of them are live viruses. Also when I took the kids to the Pedi she let me in thru her office so I wouldn't be exposed to other sick kids.
Posts.Title: How help my wife through chemo? Husband11 Ninja

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 06:46PM bkc wrote: Kerrymac- My hands also got very dry and cracked. I used Dr. Scholl's ultra overnight foot cream at night and in 2 days my hands were softer than they have ever been. Lavender scent so it smells good to. I didn't avoid the kids but didn't kiss them on the mouth and used alot of antibacterial soap. Didn't ever get sick but could have been just luck. Plus had my chemo in the summer so missed most of cold season.
Posts.Title: How help my wife through chemo? Husband11 Ninja
